dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look at how birds live in the city, emphasizing the scavenging nature of their existence. We see birds eating off the ground, out of trash cans, even swooping down to steal a piece of donut out of the hand of a sleepy citize just leaving his house. The last bird we see flies towards the house of the Littl family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first hint of morning light enters the Little household. All is quiet and peaceful. MR. AND MRS. LITTLE are asleep in bed. THROUGH the window we see bird eyes spying in on them.

dialogues.speaker: ALARM CLOCK
dialogues.text: BLASTING a rendition of "STARS AND STRIPES FOREVER" into the Little's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bird flies off the window sill and disappears. Even before they're awake, Mr. and Mrs. Little's feet begin swiveling in time to the music. Then we hear a BABY CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: sitting upright in bed. She turns OFF the ALARM. On her ring finger is a beautiful engagement ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Little gets out of bed and we FOLLOW her OVER TO a crib wherein sits a beautiful nine-month-old girl, MARTHA LITTLE. Mrs. Little picks her up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Moomy's here. No more crying. Martha's diaper is askew. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Ohh... See this is what happens when Daddy changes you at 4!A.M. (calls out) Boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ALARM CLOCK. It GOES OFF and makes a FACTORY WHISTLE NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: in the lower bunk. He grumbles and turns over.

dialogues.speaker: UPPER BUNK
dialogues.text: A tiny lump under a blanket as it begins to move. Moments later a tail emerges from underneath the sheet. It moves tentatively, as if checking things out. The tail is followed by a rear-end dressed in bright pajamas with a print pattern featuring pineapples (or something funnier) and then the remainder of a four-inch body. It is STUART. (For those who haven't read the book or seen the movie, Stuart is a mouse.) Stuart is sleepy. He staggers around almost blindly. He almost steps off the edge of his bunk. This wakes him more completely. He rubs his eyes and stretches and smiles. Grabbing hold of a miniature fireman's pole built out of tinker toys, slides down to the lower bunk and crosses over to George's sleeping head.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: George, wake up. George is a hard wake-up. Stuart stands on George's chest and jumps up and down.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I know. But it's the first day of Pee Wee Soccer. Our first game. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's eyes pop open and he gasps. He's immediately nervous.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Soccer? Uh... No I can't today, I... caught a cold while I was sleeping. He sneezes and blows Stuart halfway across the bed. Stuart scrambles back quickly. He grabs George's glasses from the nightstand and masterfully engineers them onto George's face. He taps on the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: You'll be fine. Come on, we're gonna be great. We're gonna play like Brazilians! Stuart takes off his pajama top and soccer-kicks it acros the room into a hamper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Little is rushing around the kitchen, feeding the baby and making breakfast for everyone at the same time. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her TO the kitchen table as she puts another spoonful of cereal into the baby's mouth. The baby is sitting in her highchair between her brothers who are in their uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Stuart, don't forget your water bottle. George... Mr. Little enters on the run.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (finishing her sentence) --.- don't forget your cleats. (to Mrs. Little) You look especially beautiful today.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Some people just know how to wear oatmeal. They kiss. MARTHA BABBLES something that is not a word. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (excited) Did you hear that? She said ‘bluh-bluh,' her first word. Where's the baby book? I'1l write it down.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm... not sure that's actually a word.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Your Uncle Crenshaw said that every Little starts talking by nine months.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Yes and in Uncle Crenshaw's case never stops.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Are you both coming to the game?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Wouldn't miss it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Frederick, this soccer game is making me very...

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: «+. proud? He starts opening a jar.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Anxious. Especially ‘bout... She points at Stuart who is trying to get jelly out of a jar. He almost falls in, but then swings himself out safely onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: He's fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (sotto) But all those boys... stomping around with cleats... What if someone...? She pantomimes squishing and recoils.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Honey, he's a Little. We're all natural athletes. (handing her the jar) Could you open this? She does. The toast is burning, the TEA is WHISTLING, the BABY is CRYING, and Mrs. Little is clearly overwhelmed. Then the baby pours the remainder of the cereal onto her head and throws the bowl onto the floor. Mrs. Little quickly lifts her from the highchair and rushes her to th sink.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Okay, that's it for you. (calling out) Snowbell. Food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNOWBELL perks up.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Food! ! He dashes pell-mell into the kitchen, careening around corners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowbell rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Tuna? Is it tuna? Or herring. Or -- dare I say it -- is it lox? Oh, please be lox! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (points to the glop on the floor) That's for you, Snow.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh great. It's glop. (starts eating it) Look what I'm reduced to. I'ma paper towel with hair.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) How about it, boys? Are we ready to play some soccer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is in progress. George is trying, but some of the kids are bigger, more aggressive and better co- ordinated.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The whole pack blows right by him. Among the parents, Mr. and Mrs. Little watch the game. Mrs. Little holds Martha.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Frederick, why are all the kids running one way while George is going the other way?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Well, he, uh... he's an independent spirit. What bothers me is, every kid has had a chance to play except Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Well, there's plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Plenty of time? There's forty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: He did an excellent job handing out the orange slices. And that's not as easy as it looks. He gives her a look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: All right. I admit it. I'm glad he's not in the game. I don't want him to get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Honey, it's Pee Wee Soccer. Nobody gets hurt.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A KID on George's team gets kicked in the stomach. He howls in pain. A whistle blows, stopping the action. The COACH runs out to help.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Irwin?

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN, (KID)
dialogues.text: (doubled over) Do I look all right?

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: You'd better substitute.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH
dialogues.text: Only Stuart is available.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: (to his assistant) Tie game. We could play with just ten.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE
dialogues.text: (an obnoxious kid) Yeah, but we have George, so it would be like having nine.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Wallace! We'll have none of that.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE
dialogues.text: Why not? That's how you talk to Mom.

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: Come on, Coach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: «+. Stuart. Go in for Irwin.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Yes!! He runs in.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Stuart's teammates look as if this seals their doom.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Stuart!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (nervously) Oh my.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: (to Stuart) Try to... He gives up. Whistle. Play is back in. The ball is kicked around by a pack of boys. Stuart chases the pack. The pack turns and Stuart is nearly trampled.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (rises) I'm going down there and snatching him off that field. Mr. Little holds her down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The ball comes flying out of the pack towards the goal that George and Stuart's team are attacking. The closest players to the ball are George and Stuart, who were lagging behind the play.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: (hysterical) Get it! George! Go after it! George and Stuart from opposite directions run towards th ball. Stuart is closer, but George is faster and is getting to the ball first.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: George, shoot! Wallace appears out on the wing.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE
dialogues.text: Pass me the ball, lame-o!

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: George, shoot! George shuts his eyes and kicks at the exact moment Stuar reaches the ball. The ball flies off the ground with Stuart pasted to it, screaming. The ball hits Wallace -- hard -- in the middle of his face and ricochets off. Wallace, knocked loopy, has the imprint of a mouse on his forehead. The ball -- still flying. Stuart still on it, screaming. It sails into the goal. The GUN GOES OFF. The game is over. George is mobbed by happy teammates. He is literally carried off on their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: GOAL
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Little run in to look for Stuart. The ball is on the ground. They pick it up. No Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: STUART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Enmeshed in the goal netting, dangling upside-down by one foot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Do I get an assist? Then he falls several feet into the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're preparing for bed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: He just looked so small out there. So... lacking in bigness. Does he have to go back next week?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Honey, we have to give him room to grow.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: I give him room. I let him drive his car to school. No other mother does that.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Yes, but with George walking right beside him every step.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: I let him go out without his galoshes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: When it's not raining.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: So? How much more room do I need to give him?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: A little more than you're giving him now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: -+. How little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are in their respective bunks.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I'm worried that Mom's not going to let me play soccer anymore. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Well, she already didn't let me go out for fencing or wrestling or roller hockey.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, what does she want you to go out for?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Painting or dancing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's hard to get hurt doing those.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (glumly ) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I guess it's my fault. I'm sorry I kicked you into the goal.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: That's okay. Hey, you won the game. That's the main thing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No... the main thing was I hit Wallace in the face. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Little is pruning roses in a tiny planter in front o the house. She hears:

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Little. She looks up and sees WILL WILSON. He's George's age, African-American.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh hi, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Is George home? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Yes. He's playing with Stuart. Go on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Stuart are working on a model airplane that ha taken over the dining table. It is a bright-red replica of a WWII Grumman F4F-3 Wildcat fighter plane with a deca of an American flag and Betty Grable on the side. George is putting the propeller on. Stuart is vocally making engine noises.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stuart, hand me the pliers... Stuart? Stuart is sitting in the plane, a scarf around his neck, fantasizing.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Bogie's, twelve o'clock! I got him, Brooklyn!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stuart!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (brought back to reality) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh -- I... Wouldn't it be cool if I actually flew this thing?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Mom's gonna let you fly a plane. Check the wires in there. Will enters.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hi, George. Hi, Stuart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (delighted) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hi, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey, neat plane.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey, George, you want to take a break for awhile? I brought my chess set.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: But what about the plane?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I want to play with Will for awhile. We can tell Stuart is dejected and that this is for him. The older boys exit. Stuart turns to sleeping on the work table.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey, Snowbell? (louder) Snowbell1! 13. 12 painful Snowbell Snowbell, wakes up, noisily -- snorting and clearing his throat.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Whu?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Want to help me fix the plane?

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Let me explain something to you. I am trying -- desperately -- to cling to the last shreds of dignity I possess. I'm licking up after that little monster... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+. I've had my claws trimmed so I won't scratch 'Mommy's Little Precious'... and now a mouse -- because he's lonely and desperate for companionship asks -- as a last resort -- to become his ‘playmate.’ The gall. The temerity... Yeah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart climbs back into the cockpit of the PLANE. He opens up the instruction book. He reaches under the dashboard. His sweater catches on the on/off switch and clicks it ON by accident. Suddenly the MOTOR WHIRS into action. Snowbell, hearing the noise, screams, jumps up and dashes out. Before Stuart realizes what is happening, the airplane is taxiing down the table. George and Will run in and yell over the NOISE of the ENGINE.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stuart, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (panicked, yelling back) I'm not doing it. It won't turn off. The plane hits the remote, knocking it off the table. It breaks. The plane flies off the table and into the next room. George and Will run after it. As they enter the dining room, the PLANE BUZZES their heads.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stuart!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This is cool! All my brother does is jam crayons up his nose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Snowbell runs in. The PLANE BUZZES him and he dashes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Mr. Little is coming downstairs with a paper kite.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Who wants to help me fly the kite? The PLANE RIPS through the kite.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Stuart. Stop that this minute. George and Will run in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He can't. Stuart yells, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: At least he's indoors, nothing bad can happen. At that exact moment, Mrs. Little opens the front door, carrying a freshly-cut bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen prettier roses? The PLANE RIPS through the bouquet and flies outside.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Stuart! All the Littles run outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They chase Stuart across Fifth Avenue into the park. Stuart has rose petals stuck to his face, blinding him. Screaming, he frantically brushes them off -- just in tim to see a group of nuns. He barely avoids hitting them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stuart covers his eyes and screams as the plane disappear behind some bushes. We hear STUART SCREAM, then we hear the sound of a CRASH. When Stuart opens his eyes, he discovers that both he and the plane have collided with a thick bush and both wings are dangling precariously at the side. Stuart crawls out of the wreckage and scampers down to th ground. We hear the anxious voices of the entire Little family as they race toward him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Stuart! Stuart! Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I'm okay. Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Fine?! It's ruined! Stuart, you destroyed it!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (feeling like a failure) I didn't mean to, George. I'm sorry. I'm really sorry. We'll fix it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: No, you won't! That is going in the trash. It's much too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Thanks, Stuart. George picks up the wreckage, throws it in the trash, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Little) Now, honey --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: He could easily have been killed. Painting or dancing. Those are his choices. And I'm no longer too sure about dancing -- you don't know what can happen. I'll make lunch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She leaves. Stuart and Mr. Little are alone.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Since she has Little Martha her protective, maternal instincts are running somewhat amok.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Also she just loves you so much, Stuart... it's hard for her to think of you in danger.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: This has been a bad day. Mom wants me to paint, George is mad at me and you and Mom are fighting.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Well... it's not one of our best days, but it's not that bad. The thing about being a Little is you always see the bright side. Every cloud has a silver lining.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Every cloud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart is sitting at a miniature school desk on the top o a regular school desk. He is dwarfed by a huge book propped open on a stand before him. We hear everyone in the class turning the page. Stuart crosses over to his book, grabs hold of the bottom of the mammoth page, and walks it from one side of the book to the other.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Okay, does anyone know the difference between longitude and latitude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We scan the class. Nobody moves. A BOY in the rear cautiously volunteers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (BOY)
dialogues.text: Is that like when somebody has a bad latitude?

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: No. Interesting try, though. Anybody else? Stuart peers out from behind his book and raises his tiny hand.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Longitude and latitude refer to the imaginary lines that go around the Earth, that help us measure where we are. Longitude measures east and west, latitude measures north and south.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (pleased) Now there's a boy who's done his homework. Very good, Stuart. Very good. A few KIDS look at him and roll their eyes. Someone whispers.

dialogues.speaker: WALLACE
dialogues.text: Teacher's pet.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Yeah? What about the hamster? A few kids giggle. A SCHOOL BELL RINGS signalling the end of the school day. Kids jump out of their seats and hurry for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway is lined with lockers. Stuart's locker is smaller than the others. As Stuart tosses things into his locker, kids prepare to go home. Stuart calls to a BOY at a nearby locker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey, Tony, I was wondering if you'd like to come over to my house this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (BOY)
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry, pal, I can't. Soccer practice.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (nods understandingly and turns to another boy) Hey, Mark...?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Piano lessons.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey, Irwin?

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: A creepy-looking kid with his shirt mis-buttoned and sticking through his fly. Irwin is aggressively picking his nose.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Uh... Nothing. Stuart slides down his desk and gets into a tiny red car parked alongside it. He puts his knapsack in the back seat and takes off following a red line painted alongside the lockers just for him. He HONKS whenever someone gets in his way. Suddenly George runs over to him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, Stu, some of the guys are going over to Will's to play basketball for a while.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) Well, they... didn't exactly mention that you were invited. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh... that's okay. I'm busy anyway.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just tell Mom I walked you home, okay? George runs off. Stuart, nodding sadly, drives off alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart is driving quietly down the sidewalk. He's gone abaut a block when suddenly he hears a loud SQUAWK and then sees what appears to be a wounded BIRD fall out of the sky and land in the passenger seat of his car.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh, my -- ! Startled, her swerves the CAR all over the sidewalk until SCREECHING to a stop. He stares at the bird, lying in his car. Although, we don't know it yet, her name is MARGALO. Stuart stares at her with a mixture of concern and fascination. She is definitely a unique creature, not much bigger than Stuart. She is wearing a pilot's leather helmet, and goggles and looks like what Amelia Earhart might have looked like if she was a bird. Cautiously he reaches out to touch her.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Miss?... Miss?... Are you alive? She doesn't answer. Stuart listens for her heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: She's alive! Slamming on the gas pedal, Stuart RACES quickly down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Out of the way, please. Injured bird, coming through.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BIRD'S-EYE VIEW
dialogues.text: The shadow of a huge bird crosses over it. We hear Jaws- like theme MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Stuart and Margalo are zipping through pedestrian traffic when she opens her eyes and looks groggily at Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: What's going on? Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: It's all right. You're going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: (looks around) But where's Falcon?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Falcon? What Falcon? At that instant, a huge terrifying BIRD swoops down from the sky. All Stuart can make out is a sharp beak and terrifying pointed talons rushing at him. Margalo yells to Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: That Falcon!! Drive! Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh, my!!! Stuart GUNS the CAR and goes shooting down the sidewalk. Margalo turns defiantly in the back seat and waves her fist at the bird.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Get lost, you disgusting vulture!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (nervously) Do we really want to antagonize him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Just drive! (cursing again at the hawk) Eat_my feathers, you vile buzzard!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: See, you're just reducing yourself to his level. Stuart drives faster. People scatter in all directions. A metal grate begins to open like a drawbridge on the sidewalk in front of him. Stuart can't get around it.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Uh-oh, we've got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: You can make it! Don't slow down. Like Smokey and the Bandit, he takes a deep breath, aims full-speed at the grate, and goes sailing over the top.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: as they are careening through the air.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: See! What'd I tell ya? Stuart's eyes are lit up with excitement. He is thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Yeah!!!!

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: lands safely on the down-sloping grate and continues alon the sidewalk, but the massive bird is still in full pursuit. Stuart SCREECHES around a corner and spots a stack of plumbing supplies piled in front of a building. He zooms into an eight-foot long plastic pipe, about six inches in diameter. Peering out the far end he can see Falcon landing on the ground and looking around in total confusion. He has lost them. The Falcon flies away. Stuart lets out a deep sigh. Margalo looks up at Stuart and whispers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Nice going, friend.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Friend? He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart is wrapping her wing with gauze. A doll's medical kit is open beside him.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I wish my mom were here. She'd do a much better job. Why don't we take off your scarf.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Good idea. I -- She gasps.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: My pin. It's...

dialogues.speaker: STICKPIN
dialogues.text: With a pearl on the head of it. However, part of the pearl is gone, leaving a jagged crater.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: It must have happened when Falcon smashed into me.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Oh, gee, that's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Yeah... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey, who was that big bird? And why was he after you?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Falcon? Oh, I accidentally flew into his territory.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: His territory?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Yeah. He thinks he owns the sky. Well, he can't tell me where to fly!... Although if you hadn't shown up... Hey, who are you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh. (bows ) Forgive me. My name is Stuart. Stuart Little.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: I'm Margalo. She curtseys.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (loves her name) Margalo...

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: So tell me, Stuart Little, do you actually live here?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. I'ma real Little. I'm the middle child. The middle Little.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Cute. You got some nice digs here. Very plush.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well, I'm kind of, uh... I don't exactly... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (gently) Are you... homeless?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well... yeah. Now I don't mind, 's you understand. I like it. It 25. 19 just now with my injured wing, if I have to go back out on the street, well... Hey, I'll survive.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh no, you can't go back out on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the street, not while you're hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well um... is there anyplace around here I can crash?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Crash? You already crashed.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: No. I mean is there anyplace around here I can lie down for a while? Maybe just a little box? You know like one of those jewelry boxes with those soft linings? like those.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I know just the thing. I'1l be right back. Meanwhile, you can use my cat's bed. Margalo recoils.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: You have a cat?!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry about Snowbell. He wouldn't hurt a fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowbell sees a fly. Quick as a wink, he air and swallows it.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: I've had better, I've had worse. He heads for the house.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: 20 jumps into the  21 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowbell enters the kitchen through the "doggy" door and saunters over to his water bowl. Suddenly he sees Margalo in his bed and nearly jumps out of his skin.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Aaaa!!

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't mean to scare you.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Scare me! That's a laugh. (laughs) Hear that? That was a laugh. Snowbell now goes through a series of threatening poses and hissing sounds, then starts choking.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Hairball. Major hairball. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: And yet we continue to lick ourselves. Unbelievable. Stuart returns.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Hey, Snowbell, meet Margalo. She's going to be staying with us for a while.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Staying?! Are you out of your mind? Stuart, you can't just drag stray birds in here. What do you think this is, a halfway house? It's not sanitary. I mean, look at her, she's filthy -- no offense. She could have germs. And how do you know she's not a vagrant or a thief? Am I being too vague? Get rid of her! Mrs. Little's voice can be heard coming from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi, we're home. Sorry we're late. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (yells) Little hi, Little low.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Little hey, Little ho.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: What the heck was that?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) Oh, that's... how we greet each other.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: (pleased) Never mind. You're in for it now. Mrs. Little hates when animals walk in here off the street. She chases my friends out with a broom. When she sees this, she's going to throw a fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Little standing over Margalo, cooing.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Ooohhh... such a pretty little birdie. She cups Margalo in her hands and lifts her up, making kissing noises. Snowbell shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: I don't understand. If I live to be eight, I will never understand.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I found her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Found me? He did more than that. He saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: He did? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Mom, can she crash here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN ON a jewelry box that has been converted into an ornate bedroom suite. A tiny ballerina swirls on the uppermost level of the box and below it there is a holder for a tiny toothbrush and a bar of soap. The bottom drawer has been pulled out and turned into a bed, complet with a lace doily for a bedspread. It is a surprisingly opulent setting.

dialogues.speaker: STUART, (0.S)
dialogues.text: What do you think? REVEAL Margalo gazing at her new "home" as Stuart waits expectantly for her reaction. Mr. and Mrs. Little watch from a discreet distance. Margalo turns away.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: What? What don't you like? Margalo sniffles and wipes her eyes with her good wing.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: I never... I mean nobody ever... it's so beautiful. Stuart is very happy.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: But where will your mother keep her jewelry? Mrs. Little steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry about that. The only thing I really value is my engagement ring. She shows it. Sunlight coming through the window, catches the ring and it shines very brightly.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Wow, that's beautiful. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: It's been worn for five generations of Little women, I don't mean little women, I -- well, let's just say it's very, very special to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: But now where will you keep it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, I never take it off. Except to do the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Ah...

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: And half the time I do ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well, I'll just stay ‘til my wing heals.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Stay as long as you like. Mr. and Mrs. Little exit.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Just remember. Guests are like fish. After two days they start to stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear MARTHA WAILING away. CLOSEUP of a dish of glop hitting the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Snowbell... Snowbell reluctantly starts licking up the glop.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: How about I spill something and we get the kid to lick it up?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: feeding Margalo with a little spoon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs. She exits. 30. 24

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Stuart, I'm full.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Full? You eat like a bird.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Come on, Stuart, time for school.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not going to school today.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: No. I'm staying home to take care of Margalo...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Well, guess again. You are going to school and I'll take care of Margalo. And wear your rubbers and in art class don't run with scissors. I'1l get your backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart's a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (to Margalo) She's a little over-protective. You know... mothers.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well, I don't really know.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: See, my mom just kinda one day... wasn't there anymore.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: It's kind of hard even to remember her now... I only remember two things. She used to sing to me and she... gave me that pearl pin...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Oh... the one that broke?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was part of our nest when I was a baby. I've had it ever since.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Gee, I'm sorry. (impressed) So you've been completely on your own all your life.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I'll bet it's been scary.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Hey... it's been an adventure.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I wish I had some adventures. I'm only allowed to paint.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Hey, life is an adventure. Just walking out that door is an adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowbell enters.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWBELL
dialogues.text: Has anyone seen my tinkle ball? George appears with his schoolbooks in tow.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Come on, Stu. We're late.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: (to Stuart) Go for it, kid. The adventure begins.  25 26 27 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart steps outside the front door and immediately trips over Snowbell's tinkle ball and rolls down the front steps. He stands up, shakes his head to clear it.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Well, that feels like enough adventure for one day. He turns and is immediately whacked by a thrown rolled-up newspaper. Again, he clears his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha in a stroller. Mrs. Little is taking her out for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Margalo, Martha and I are going out for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (to Martha) Say, bye, birdie. Bye... (discouraged) Nothing. They exit. Margalo is alone. She flaps her wings a little, but the bandage is restricting her. Looking around to make doubly certain that she's alone, she removes the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: (pleased) Ahhh... She takes off and flies. She goes out the window and on to the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lands and breathes in the fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Fresh air... From behind her we see the falcon soaring above. Margalo doesn't know he's there. The falcon draws a bead on her and swoops down straight at her -- closer and closer, until... he lands right behind her. Margalo turns, startled. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs. 33. 27

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Falcon! (whispers) ... You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: FALCON, (BIRD)
dialogues.text: (slightly sarcastic) Aw, I'm sorry. How's it going, babe!

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: (nervously) Fine...

dialogues.speaker: FALCON
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, then what's holding things up?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well, I --

dialogues.speaker: FALCON
dialogues.text: You've been here two days. How long does it take to steal one little ring? Usually, you're in and out the same day.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: She only takes the ring off to do the dishes and the last two nights her husband did them.

dialogues.speaker: FALCON
dialogues.text: Aw, that's sweet. Does he wear a little apron?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Hey, don't pressure me, okay? Have I ever let you down?

dialogues.speaker: FALCON
dialogues.text: (with real admiration) Never. You're the best. The best girl I ever had working for me. I never saw anybody do the injured wing scam like you do it. ‘Help me, save me, the big falcon is after me.'

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Speaking of which you hit me kind of hard. You broke my pin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FALCON
dialogues.text: What? That stupid thing your mother gave you? Trash. I wouldn't pick my nose with it. Look, take all the time you need. Just get me that ring. He flies off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Little and George are at the table. Mr. Little nudges Mrs. Little and they glance down. On the floor, near the big table is a little table set fo two. Stuart gallantly holds out a chair for Margalo who sits down. Stuart serves her a tiny hamburger on a bun, then picks up a handful of peas from a small serving bowl He juggles the peas. He then gets them to roll down his arm into her plate. He smiles proudly. Just then, a pea lands on his head, squishing. He winces. Margalo bursts out laughing. Stuart wipes the pea off his head and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Little prepares to do the dishes. She takes off her ring. Margalo notices. O.S. MARTHA CRIES.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh... Mr. Little enters.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: You go ahead, I'1l do the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, but you did them last night.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: For you I would do dishes every night.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Aww... She kisses him and exits. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Margalo) I just didn't want to change the baby. (with distaste) Phui. He laughs. Margalo forces a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart and Margalo are in the front seat of Stuart's car. They're sharing popcorn and are apparently at a drive-in movie, because we can hear DIALOGUE from an old romantic MOVIE.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Are you cold?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. REVEAL that they are watching an old movie on a portable television.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: I guess when the weather gets too cold you'll just... fly south?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Well... to tell you the truth I've... never flown south. It's... kind of a dream of mine. Get out of the cold windy city... catch that jet stream... fruit trees... millions of new birds to meet... I hear it's paradise.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (surprised) Then how come you haven't done it?

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Oh... something always stops me. A shadow passes over them. It's a cloud passing the moon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Yeah, something's always stopping me too. Everybody around here -- Mom, George, the kids on the soccer team -- they all think I'm too small to accomplish anything.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Hey -- the way I see it -- you're as big as you feel.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Yeah... Boy, I'm really glad you fell in my car. I mean I'm not glad you fell, I just mean -- have some more popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: Okay. She picks out more popcorn, then reacts.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: What -- ? She pulls out her stickpin, fully repaired.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: My pin! It's fixed! How -- ?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: (modestly) Oh, it was no big deal. You know, on my way home from school, I drive right past the place where you crashed down into my car so I just got down on the ground and I crawled around for a while and bingo there it was -- in a crack on the sidewalk. Then all I had to do was take it home, work on it in the basement in my dad's workshop and one, two, three, good as new.

dialogues.speaker: MARGALO
dialogues.text: No, Stuart, it's not... it's much, much better. She snuggles up to him as they watch the movie.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Little start making their bed. Everything they do -- turning down the bed cover, pulling back the blankets -- they do in perfect harmony.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Isn't it nice that Stuart has a friend?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think Stuart thinks of her as a 'friend.'

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: I mean he's smitten. He's infatuated. He's bedazzled.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Stuart?!

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: M-hm.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: But he's... a baby.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Boys start having crushes really young. They put the pillows on the bed. Mrs. Little is thinking about his.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LITTLE
dialogues.text: Frederick... did you have... a lot of crushes?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LITTLE
dialogues.text: (smiles at her) I'm still having one. He turns off the light.

dialogues.text: A family musicale. They sing around the piano. Margalo watches. The MUSIC CONTINUES OVER: (CONTINUED)
